messages.content: Use Ktor and html dsl to render a list of json objects. Use content negotiation to optionally return json, yaml or xml directly. Use content negotiation for gzip or brotli compression.

search_query: ktor html dsl render json list content negotiation

Can you provide a code example demonstrating how to use Ktor with HTML DSL to render a list of JSON objects, including content negotiation for JSON, YAML, and XML, as well as Gzip and Brotli compression? Show the server-side implementation including necessary dependencies and configurations.
web_research_result:
Ktor is a Kotlin framework by JetBrains for building asynchronous client and server applications [softwaremill](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-0) [medium](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-1). It offers features like routing, content negotiation, and authentication [jku](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-2).

**HTML DSL**

Ktor's HTML DSL (Domain Specific Language) allows writing HTML in Kotlin code [softwaremill](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-0) [medium](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-1) [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-3). It integrates the `kotlinx.html` library, enabling interpolation of variables and building complex layouts using templates [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-3) [softwaremill](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-0) [github](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-4).

Key aspects of HTML DSL:

*   **Templates:** Ktor provides a templating engine for building complex HTML layouts [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-3). You can create hierarchies of templates with root and child templates [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-3).
*   **Extensibility:** HTML DSL allows you to write pure HTML in Kotlin, interpolate variables into views, and build complex layouts [softwaremill](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-0).
*   **Native Server Compatibility:** HTML DSL is the only templating option in Ktor that can be used with a native server [softwaremill](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-0).
*   **Usage:** To respond with HTML built using a template, use the `respondHtmlTemplate` method [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-3). Implement the `Template` interface and override the `Template.apply` method to provide HTML [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-3). Use `Placeholder` to insert content [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-3).
*   **kotlinx.html:** The `kotlinx.html` library offers a DSL to build HTML to Writer/Appendable or DOM [github](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-4). It is available for all Kotlin Multiplatform targets and browsers [github](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-4).

**Content Negotiation**

Content negotiation handles the conversion between different data formats during communication between a client and a server [jetbrains](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-5). The `ContentNegotiation` plugin in Ktor serves two primary purposes [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-6) [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-7):

*   Negotiating media types using the `Accept` and `Content-Type` headers [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-7) [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-6).
*   Serializing and deserializing content in specific formats like JSON, XML, CBOR, and ProtoBuf [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-6) [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-7).

Key aspects of content negotiation:

*   **Installation:** To use `ContentNegotiation`, include the `ktor-client-content-negotiation` artifact in the build script [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-6). On the server, install the `ContentNegotiation` plugin using the `install` function [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-7).
*   **Serialization:** Ktor supports JSON, XML, CBOR, and ProtoBuf formats out-of-the-box [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-6) [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-7). For JSON serialization, you can use `kotlinx.serialization`, Gson, or Jackson [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-6).
*   **JSON:** To serialize/deserialize JSON data, you can choose one of the following libraries: `kotlinx.serialization`, Gson, or Jackson [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-6).
*   **Usage:** The `call.respond` function sends data objects serialized in a specific format [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-8). Ktor uses the `Accept` header to choose the required converter [bookstack](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-9).
*    **Receiving:** When receiving, the `Content-Type` of the request will be used to determine which `ContentConverter` will be used to process that request [kotlincn](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-10).

**JSON Handling**

Ktor facilitates JSON serialization and deserialization using libraries like `kotlinx.serialization` [codersee](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-11) [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-6) [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-12).

Key aspects of JSON handling:

*   **Dependencies:** Add the necessary dependencies for JSON serialization, content negotiation, and logging [medium](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-13).
*   **Configuration:** Configure the `kotlinx.serialization` plugin [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-12).
*   **Content type:** You can specify the content type for the body, such as `ContentType.Application.Json` [codersee](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-11).
*   **Automatic Conversion:** The `ContentNegotiation` feature allows automatic content conversion based on `Content-Type` and `Accept` headers [kotlincn](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-10).
*   **Serialization of Lists:** `kotlinx-serialization` can be used to create lists from JSON files [stackoverflow](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-14).

**Content Negotiation for Lists**

To send a list of data as a JSON response, you need to ensure that content negotiation is properly configured [jetbrains](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-5) [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-7). This involves installing the `ContentNegotiation` plugin and configuring a JSON serializer [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-7). When responding with a list (e.g., `List<MyDataClass>`), Ktor checks the client's `Accept` header to determine the content type and uses the appropriate `ContentConverter` [kotlincn](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-10).

**Note:** As of July 15, 2024, Ktor officially supports WASM (WebAssembly), with stable support released on October 9, 2024, in version 3.0.0 [stackoverflow](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-15).
Ktor supports content negotiation and compression using plugins, allowing servers and clients to negotiate the best content format and compression algorithm to use [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/1-0) [bookstack](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/1-1).

**Content Negotiation:**

*   The `ContentNegotiation` feature handles media type negotiation between client and server using the `Accept` and `Content-Type` headers [bookstack](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/1-1).
*   It also handles serializing and deserializing content in specific formats like JSON and XML [bookstack](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/1-1).
*   Ktor provides built-in converters for JSON (Gson, Jackson, kotlinx.serialization), Protobuf, and CBOR [bookstack](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/1-1).
*   To use `ContentNegotiation` in a Ktor client, import it from `io.ktor.client.plugins.contentnegotiation.*` [stackoverflow](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/1-2).

**Compression:**

*   The `Compression` plugin allows a Ktor server to compress response bodies and a Ktor client to decompress request bodies [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/1-3).
*   It supports algorithms like gzip and deflate [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/1-0) [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/1-3).
*   By default, Ktor doesn't compress specific content types like audio, video, image, and `text/event-stream` [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/1-3).
*   The `Compression` plugin does not currently support Server-Sent Events (SSE) responses [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/1-3).
*   To use `Compression`, you need to include the `ktor-server-compression` artifact in your build script [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/1-3).
*   You can configure compression settings such as enabling specific encoders, specifying priorities, and setting conditions for compression based on content type or response size [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/1-3).
*   When the configuration block is omitted, the default configuration is used which includes the following encoders: gzip, deflate, and identity [kotlincn](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/1-4).

**Gzip and Deflate:**

*   Ktor client provides the `ContentEncoding` plugin that allows you to enable specified compression algorithms such as `gzip` and `deflate` and configure their settings [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/1-0).

**Brotli:**

*   As of July 2025, Ktor does not have built-in support for Brotli compression [kotlinlang](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/1-5).
*   To use Brotli, you can implement the `ContentEncoder` interface with a third-party library and integrate it into the `ContentEncoding` plugin [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/1-0) [kotlinlang](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/1-5).
*   Brotli generally offers better compression than Gzip [siteground](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/1-6). It was specifically designed for the web and can be faster at both compressing content on the server and decompressing it in the browser [siteground](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/1-6).

**Security Considerations:**

*   Using HTTPS with compression can make your application vulnerable to BREACH attacks [kotlincn](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/1-4). Mitigations include disabling compression, not mixing user input with secrets in responses, and adding random bytes to the output [kotlincn](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/1-4).

**Additional Notes:**

*   Under high load, there have been reports of requests failing when the server encodes response bodies [jetbrains](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/1-7). Removing the `Compression` plugin or replacing it with Netty's implementation might resolve the issue [jetbrains](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/1-7).
*   When serving compressed resources, the `Vary` header should be included in the HTTP response, but this might not be the case with the `Compression` plugin [jetbrains](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/1-8).
While a complete, runnable code example fulfilling all requirements (HTML DSL, JSON list rendering, content negotiation for JSON/YAML/XML, Gzip/Brotli compression) was not found, the search results provide the necessary components and guidance to construct such an example.

**I. Dependencies and Configuration**

1.  **Ktor Core:**  The foundation for building Ktor servers [medium](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-0).
2.  **Ktor HTML Builder:** Enables the use of HTML DSL for generating HTML responses [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-1).  Add the following dependency [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-1):

    ```kotlin
    implementation("io.ktor:ktor-server-html-builder:$ktor_version")
    ```
3.  **Ktor Content Negotiation:**  Handles media type negotiation between client and server [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-2) [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-3). Add the following dependency [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-3):

    ```kotlin
    implementation("io.ktor:ktor-server-content-negotiation:$ktor_version")
    ```
4.  **JSON Support:**  Choose one of the JSON libraries (kotlinx.serialization, Gson, or Jackson) [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-2) [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-3).  For kotlinx.serialization, add these dependencies [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-2) [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-3):

    ```kotlin
    implementation("io.ktor:ktor-serialization-kotlinx-json:$ktor_version")
    ```
    Also, add the serialization plugin [medium](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-4):

    ```kotlin
    plugins {
        kotlin("jvm") version "1.9.10"
        id("io.ktor.plugin") version "2.3.5"
        id("org.jetbrains.kotlin.plugin.serialization") version "1.8.0"
    }
    ```
5.  **XML Support:** To serialize/deserialize XML, add the `ktor-serialization-kotlinx-xml` dependency [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-2):

    ```kotlin
    implementation("io.ktor:ktor-serialization-kotlinx-xml:$ktor_version")
    ```
    Ktor also supports XML using Jackson [github](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-5).
6.  **YAML Support:** While Ktor doesn't have built-in YAML support, you can integrate it using a custom serializer with a library like `kotlinx-serialization-yaml`.
7.  **Compression:** Enables Gzip and Deflate compression [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-6) [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-7). Add the following dependency [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-7):

    ```kotlin
    implementation("io.ktor:ktor-server-compression:$ktor_version")
    ```

**II. Server-Side Implementation**

1.  **Install Plugins:** Install the `ContentNegotiation` and `Compression` plugins within your Ktor application module [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-7) [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-3):

    ```kotlin
    import io.ktor.server.application.*
    import io.ktor.server.plugins.contentnegotiation.*
    import io.ktor.server.plugins.compression.*

    fun Application.module() {
        install(ContentNegotiation) {
            json() // or gson() or jackson()
            xml()
            //register(ContentType.Application.Yaml, YamlConverter()) //Custom implementation
        }
        install(Compression) {
            gzip {
                priority = 1.0
            }
            deflate {
                priority = 0.9
                minimumSize(1024) // condition
            }
            //brotli { //Not directly supported, requires custom encoder
            //    priority = 1.1
            //}
        }
        //...
    }
    ```

2.  **Content Negotiation:** Configure the `ContentNegotiation` plugin to use the desired serializers (JSON, XML) [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-2) [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-3).  For YAML, you'll need to implement a custom `YamlConverter` and register it with the plugin [medium](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-8).

3.  **Compression:** Configure the `Compression` plugin with Gzip and Brotli (if a custom encoder is implemented) [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-6) [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-7). Note that while Ktor supports Gzip and Deflate compression, Brotli is not directly supported and might require a custom encoder [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-7) [kotlinlang](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-9).

4.  **HTML DSL and Routing:**  Define routes that use HTML DSL to render the list of JSON objects [medium](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-10) [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-1).

    ```kotlin
    import io.ktor.server.application.*
    import io.ktor.server.response.*
    import io.ktor.server.routing.*
    import kotlinx.html.*
    import io.ktor.http.*

    @Serializable
    data class Item(val name: String, val value: Int)

    fun Route.listItemsRoute() {
        get("/items") {
            val items = listOf(
                Item("Item 1", 10),
                Item("Item 2", 20)
            )

            call.respondHtml(HttpStatusCode.OK) {
                head {
                    title("Items List")
                }
                body {
                    h1 { +"List of Items" }
                    ul {
                        items.forEach { item ->
                            li { +"${item.name}: ${item.value}" }
                        }
                    }
                }
            }
        }
    }

    fun Application.module() {
        routing {
            listItemsRoute()
        }
    }
    ```

5.  **Serving Content:** Use the `respond*` functions to send the content to the client. Ktor chooses the appropriate serializer based on the `Accept` header of the request [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-3).

**III. Brotli Compression**

*   Ktor doesn't offer built-in Brotli support [kotlinlang](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-9) [jetbrains](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-11).
*   To enable Brotli, you might need to implement a custom `ContentEncoder` and integrate it into the `ContentEncoding` plugin [kotlinlang](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-9) [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-6).
*   Alternatively, pre-compress files using Brotli and serve them directly [ktor](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-7) [jetbrains](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-11).

**IV. Additional Considerations**

*   **Content Types:**  Ensure the correct content types are set in the responses (e.g., `ContentType.Application.Json`, `ContentType.Application.Xml`, `ContentType.Application.Yaml`) [medium](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-8).
*   **Error Handling:** Implement proper error handling to catch exceptions during serialization and compression [medium](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-8).
*   **Asynchronous Operations:**  Use Kotlin's coroutines for handling asynchronous operations [medium](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-10).
*   **Testing:**  Write unit and integration tests to verify the functionality [github](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-5).

This information should allow you to construct a Ktor application that meets the specified requirements. Remember to consult the Ktor documentation for the most up-to-date information and best practices.
